summary: international standards for documenting, referencing, tracking, and shipping samples would save valuable time in a pandemic. many clinical laboratories cannot release patient samples without preapproved protocols from an Institutional Review Board. virologists from universities outside of the WHO laboratory network have had difficulty getting access to samples. a lack of training, mentoring, and formal standards for biosafety leaves researchers at unnecessary risk of infection. some experts believe that the dominant strain of flu originated from a laboratory [7]. the public may not forgive the scientific community at large for an epidemic that starts in a laboratory. the scientific community has a responsibility to take reasonable precautions to prevent accidents and to train researchers in safety training. the strict safety regulations proposed for laboratories in Boston directly result from three laboratory-acquired cases of tularemia [9] transmission electron micrography (108,000) reveals two avian influenza A virions.
